title: EngineInternalError
text:
EngineInternalError



exception ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.exceptions.EngineInternalError

Bases: Exception

Indicates that the workflow engine has encountered an internal error.

An error of this type means that something has gone wrong with the workflow engine itself during
the requested operation. Such an error should not usually be encountered and may indicate the
presence of a bug that should be reported to the engine maintainer.

title: EngineInternalError > EngineInternalError > EngineInternalError
text:

Indicates that the workflow engine has encountered an internal error.

An error of this type means that something has gone wrong with the workflow engine itself during
the requested operation. Such an error should not usually be encountered and may indicate the
presence of a bug that should be reported to the engine maintainer.

title: IAsyncDatapin
text:
IAsyncDatapin



class ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.iasyncworkflow.IAsyncDatapin

Bases: IAsyncElement, abc.ABC

Provides a runtime placeholder for some value of a particular type.

The placeholder changes as the workflow runs. It can be linked to other datapins via direct
links or equations.

title: IComponent
text:
IComponent



class ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.iworkflow.IComponent

Bases: IElement, IDatapinContainer, abc.ABC

Provides for a black box analysis.

A black box analysis is defined as taking a set of inputs, executing, and then returning a set
of outputs.

The black box may be a solver, simulation, co-simulation, calculation, or other third-party
analysis. While state may be kept as an optimization to help performance for slow-to-start
tools, the component definition does not require it so that the work can be parallelize onto an
HPC cluster.

The “black box” term is synonymous with integration and analysis. It is the preferred term used
in the Ansys Engineering Workflow API and documentation.

title: IComponent > IComponent > IComponent
text:

The black box may be a solver, simulation, co-simulation, calculation, or other third-party
analysis. While state may be kept as an optimization to help performance for slow-to-start
tools, the component definition does not require it so that the work can be parallelize onto an
HPC cluster.

The “black box” term is synonymous with integration and analysis. It is the preferred term used
in the Ansys Engineering Workflow API and documentation.

title: IComponent > Overview
text:
Overview

Properties





pacz_url

URL to the PACZ file or directory.

title: IComponent > Import detail
text: Import detail

title: IComponent > Property detail
text:
Property detail



property IComponent.pacz_url: str | None

Abstractmethod



URL to the PACZ file or directory.

The URL may be absolute or relative. If relative, the URL must be relative to the workflow
definition. While all components are represented by PACZ definitions, in the short term,
many components are not currently defined in this way. If there is not a PACZ definition of
the component, the method returns None. In such cases, you must fall back on
engine-specific methods to determine what the component type is.

engine-specific methods to determine what the component type is.

title: Property
text:
Property



class ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.datatypes.Property

Provides a configurable setting on some component or algorithm in the workflow.

This configurable setting cannot be linked to other variables or properties. Unless a property
is explicitly documented as supporting it, values should not be changed while the workflow is
running. Examples that may support modification would be convergence criteria for an
optimization algorithm.

title: NameCollisionError
text:
NameCollisionError



exception ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.exceptions.NameCollisionError

Bases: ValueError

Indicates that an operation has failed because of a name collision.

An error of this type means that the name requested is already in use and cannot be reused.

Engine maintainers should only raise this error if the operation in question is otherwise valid
and could be retried successfully with a different, unique name.

title: NameCollisionError > NameCollisionError > NameCollisionError
text:
exception ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.exceptions.NameCollisionError

Bases: ValueError

Indicates that an operation has failed because of a name collision.

An error of this type means that the name requested is already in use and cannot be reused.

Engine maintainers should only raise this error if the operation in question is otherwise valid
and could be retried successfully with a different, unique name.

title: NameCollisionError > Import detail
text: Import detail

title: ValueOutOfRangeError
text:
ValueOutOfRangeError



exception ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.exceptions.ValueOutOfRangeError

Bases: ValueError

Indicates that an operation has failed because the requested value is out of range.

An error of this type is most commonly used when an attempt to set a datapin value fails
for one of these reasons:

The requested value violates the datapin’s boundaries.

The datapin has enumerated values and the requested value is not in the enumeration.

title: ValueOutOfRangeError > ValueOutOfRangeError > ValueOutOfRangeError
text:

An error of this type is most commonly used when an attempt to set a datapin value fails
for one of these reasons:

The requested value violates the datapin’s boundaries.

The datapin has enumerated values and the requested value is not in the enumeration.

title: Contribute
text:
Contribute

Overall guidance on contributing to a PyAnsys library appears in the
Contributing topic
in the PyAnsys developer’s guide. Ensure that you are thoroughly familiar
with this guide before attempting to contribute to the Ansys Engineering Workflow API.

The following contribution information is specific to the Ansys Engineering Workflow API.

title: Contribute > Install in developer mode
text:
Install in developer mode

Installing the ansys-engineeringworkflow-api package in developer mode allows
you to modify the source and enhance it. This package supports Python 3.10 through 3.13
on Windows, MacOS, and Linux.

For a local development version, you can create a clean virtual environment with this command:

You can then activate this virtual environment with the command appropriate for your operating system:

Linux



macOS



Windows



Next, install the development version of the ansys-engineeringworkflow-api package
with these commands:

title: Contribute > Build documentation
text:
Build documentation

Install the required dependencies for the documentation with this command:

To build documentation, run the usual rules provided in the Sphinx
Makefile for your operating system:

Linux



macOS



Windows

title: Contribute > Post issues
text:
Post issues

Use the Ansys Engineering Workflow API Issues
page to report bugs and request new features.

When possible, use the issue templates provided. If your issue does not fit into one
of the templates, you can click the link for opening a blank issue.

To reach the PyAnsys support team, email pyansys.core@ansys.com.

title: Contribute > Verify style and unit tests
text:
Verify style and unit tests

If required, from the command line, you can call commands like black, isort, and flake8.
You can also call unit testing commands like pytest. However, running these commands does not
guarantee that your project is being tested in an isolated environment, which is why you
might consider using tox.

title: Contribute > Test
text:
Test

You can install the dependencies required for testing with this command:

You can then run the tests via pytest with this command:

title: Contribute > Adhere to code style
text:
Adhere to code style

The Ansys Engineering Workflow API follows the PEP8 standard as indicated in the
PyAnsys developer’s guide and implements style checking using
pre-commit.

To ensure your code meets minimum code styling standards, run these commands:

You can also install this as a pre-commit hook by running this command:

This way, it’s not possible for you to push code that fails the style checks:

title: Contribute > Distribute
text:
Distribute

If you would like to create either source or wheel files, start by running this
command to install the building requirements:

Then, run these commands:

class ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.iworkflow.IControlStatement

Provides an element in the workflow that contains children and how they are executed.

title: IControlStatement > Method detail
text:
Method detail



abstractmethod IControlStatement.get_elements() -> Mapping[str, IElement]

Get all elements of the control statement.

Because Python dictionaries are ordered, the order in which elements appear in the map
may be significant, depending on the engine/workflow instance implementation.
For example, some workflows may execute each element in a control statement
in a defined order, which should be reflected here.

Returns

Mapping[python:str, IElement]

Child elements of the control statement. Each key is the short name (relative to
the parent element) of the corresponding element object.

title: IControlStatement > Method detail > get_elements

may be significant, depending on the engine/workflow instance implementation.
For example, some workflows may execute each element in a control statement
in a defined order, which should be reflected here.

Returns

Mapping[python:str, IElement]

Child elements of the control statement. Each key is the short name (relative to
the parent element) of the corresponding element object.

title: Getting started
text:
Getting started

The Ansys Engineering Workflow API supports Python 3.10 through 3.13 on Windows,
MacOS, and Linux.

Two installation modes of the ansys-engineeringworkflow-api package
are provided: user and developer. This section describes how to install
in user mode.

If you are interested in contributing to this package, see ref_contribute
for information on installing in developer mode.

title: Getting started > Installation
text:
Installation

Before installing the ansys-engineeringworkflow-api package, make sure that you
have the latest version of pip with this command:

Then, install the latest ansys-engineeringworkflow-api package with this command:

Alternatively, you can install the latest version from the project’s GitHub repository with this command:

text:
Ansys Engineering Workflow API documentation 0.1.dev0

Getting started 

Learn how to install the Ansys Engineering Workflow API.

getting_started/index

User guide 

Learn how to use the Ansys Engineering Workflow API.

user_guide/index

API reference 

Understand Ansys Engineering Workflow API endpoints, their capabilities,
and how to interact with them programmatically.

api/index

Contribute 

Learn how to contribute to the Ansys Engineering Workflow API codebase
or documentation.

contributing/index

title: The exceptions.py module
text: The exceptions.py module

title: The exceptions.py module > Summary
text:
Summary

Exceptions





EngineInternalError

Indicates that the workflow engine has encountered an internal error.

NameCollisionError

Indicates that an operation has failed because of a name collision.

ValueOutOfRangeError

Indicates that an operation has failed because the requested value is out of range.

title: The exceptions.py module > Description
text:
Description

Exception types, which allow for handling expressive errors in common situations.

title: The iasyncworkflow.py module
text: The iasyncworkflow.py module

title: The iasyncworkflow.py module > Summary
text:
Summary

Interfaces





IAsyncWorkflowEngine

Provides the interface defining the common behavior for an engineering workflow engine.

IAsyncFileBasedWorkflowEngine

Extends the IWorkflowEngine module with calls.

IAsyncWorkflowInstance

Represents an instantiated workflow instance.

IAsyncElement

Provides a component, control statement, or datapin.

IAsyncDatapinContainer

Provides an abstract base class for something that can contain datapins.

IAsyncControlStatement

Provides an element in the workflow that contains children and how they are executed.

IAsyncComponent

Provides for a black box analysis.

IAsyncDatapin

Provides a runtime placeholder for some value of a particular type.

title: The iasyncworkflow.py module > Description
text:
Description

Asynchronous API definitions.

This module contains the common API for all Ansys workflow engines, written in an
asynchronous style. It has the exact same API as the IWorkflow module and any
changes to one file must be made to the other.

Generally speaking, in addition to the exceptions already noted, implementations of
this API may raise the exceptions.EngineInternalError class to indicate
that an internal error has been encountered and should be reported to the engine
implementation maintainer.

class ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.iworkflow.IWorkflowInstance

Bases: abc.ABC

Represents an instantiated workflow instance.

title: IWorkflowInstance > Overview
text:
Overview

Abstract methods





get_state

Get the state of the workflow instance.

start_run

Set a workflow’s input datapins and start running the workflow.

get_root

Get the root element of the workflow instance.

get_element_by_name

Get an element of the workflow instance by name.

Methods





run

Set a workflow’s input datapins and run it.

title: IWorkflowInstance > Import detail
text: Import detail

title: IWorkflowInstance > Method detail
text:
Method detail



abstractmethod IWorkflowInstance.get_state() -> ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.datatypes.WorkflowInstanceState

Get the state of the workflow instance.



IWorkflowInstance.run(inputs: Mapping[str, ansys.tools.variableinterop.VariableState] = {}, reset: bool = False, validation_names: AbstractSet[str] = set(), collect_names: AbstractSet[str] = set()) -> Mapping[str, ansys.tools.variableinterop.VariableState]

Set a workflow’s input datapins and run it.

Parameters

inputs

Mapping[python:str, VariableState]

Map of datapin names to VariableState objects for all inputs to
set before running the workflow.

reset

bool, default: python:False

Whether to reset the workflow before running. If this parameter is set
to True, all run components and data links become invalid so that the
workflow runs from the beginning. However, it does not reset any input values
that have been set to non-default values. Note that setting datapin values
could also implicitly reset the states of some components.

validation_names

AbstractSet[python:str]

Names of the specific datapins or components that are required to be valid.
Setting names may enable the workflow engine to shortcut evaluation of the
workflow. If the set is non-empty, the workflow engine may choose which
portions of the workflow are run to satisfy the given datapins with the
minimum runtime.

collect_names

AbstractSet[python:str]

Names of the specific datapins or elements that are to cause the method
to return these values after running. If an element is specified, all
child datapins are recursively included.

Returns

Mapping[python:str, VariableState]

Map of output datapin names to VariableState objects for each datapin specified by
the collect_names parameter.

Raises

ValueOutOfRangeError

If one of the input values violates its datapin’s bounds or enumerated values.



abstractmethod IWorkflowInstance.start_run(inputs: Mapping[str, ansys.tools.variableinterop.VariableState], reset: bool, validation_names: AbstractSet[str]) -> None

Set a workflow’s input datapins and start running the workflow.

set before running the workflow.

reset

to True, all run components and data links become invalid so that the
workflow runs from the beginning. However, it does not reset any input values
that have been set to non-default values. Note that setting datapin values
could also implicitly reset the states of some components.

validation_names

AbstractSet[python:str]

Names of the specific datapins or components that are required to be valid.
Setting names may enable the workflow engine to shortcut evaluation of the
workflow. If the set is non-empty, the workflow engine may choose which
portions of the workflow are run to satisfy the given datapins with the
minimum runtime.

Raises

ValueOutOfRangeError

If one of the input values violates its datapin’s bounds or enumerated values.

title: WorkflowEngineInfo
text:
WorkflowEngineInfo



class ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.datatypes.WorkflowEngineInfo

Stores workflow engine information collected by the get_server_info call.

title: WorkflowEngineInfo > WorkflowEngineInfo > WorkflowEngineInfo
text:
class ansys.engineeringworkflow.api.datatypes.WorkflowEngineInfo

Stores workflow engine information collected by the get_server_info call.

title: WorkflowEngineInfo > Overview
text:
Overview

Attributes





release_year

Year portion of the release, such as 2022.

release_id

ID portion of the release, such as 2 for 2022 R2.

build

Build number.

is_release_build

Flag indicating if the release is a production release.

build_type

Build type.

version_as_string

Version of the workflow engine encoded for human consumption.

server_type

Type of server that is responding to the request.

install_location

Installation directory.

base_url

Base URL for clients to connect to.

title: WorkflowEngineInfo > Import detail
text: Import detail

title: WorkflowEngineInfo > Attribute detail
text:
Attribute detail



WorkflowEngineInfo.release_year: int

Year portion of the release, such as 2022.



WorkflowEngineInfo.release_id: int

ID portion of the release, such as 2 for 2022 R2.



WorkflowEngineInfo.build: int

Build number.



WorkflowEngineInfo.is_release_build: bool

Flag indicating if the release is a production release.

The value is False for development, alpha, beta, and other releases.



WorkflowEngineInfo.build_type: str

Build type.

This attribute must be blank for a production release. For other release types, it may include
arbitrary information like the branch that a development build was built from.



WorkflowEngineInfo.version_as_string: str

Version of the workflow engine encoded for human consumption.

For example, `2022r1 build 333 ALPHA`.



WorkflowEngineInfo.server_type: str

Type of server that is responding to the request.

The value is a string similar to 'ModelCenter' or 'optiSLang'.



WorkflowEngineInfo.install_location: str | None

Installation directory.

If the client is on the same box as the workflow engine, this optional attribute may provide the
installation folder.

Typically server-based products do not provide this field for security reasons.



WorkflowEngineInfo.base_url: str | None

Base URL for clients to connect to.

If this is a server-based product ready to receive incoming connections from remote clients,
this optional attribute may provide the base URL for clients to connect to.

Year portion of the release, such as 2022.

validation_names

AbstractSet[python:str]

Names of the specific datapins or components that are required to be valid.
Setting names may enable the workflow engine to shortcut evaluation of the
workflow. If the set is non-empty, the workflow engine may choose which
portions of the workflow are run to satisfy the given datapins with the
minimum runtime.

collect_names

AbstractSet[python:str]

Names of the specific datapins or elements that are to cause the method
to return these values after running. If an element is specified, all
child datapins are recursively included.

Raises

ValueOutOfRangeError

If one of the input values violates its datapin’s bounds or enumerated values.

title: IAsyncWorkflowInstance > Method detail > start_run
text:
abstractmethod IAsyncWorkflowInstance.start_run(inputs: Mapping[str, ansys.tools.variableinterop.VariableState], reset: bool, validation_names: AbstractSet[str]) -> str

Async



Set a workflow’s input datapins and start running the workflow.

Parameters

inputs

Mapping[python:str, VariableState]

Map of datapin names to VariableState objects for all inputs to
set before running the workflow.

reset

bool

Whether to reset the workflow before running. If this parameter is set
to True, all run components and data links become invalid so that the
workflow runs from the beginning. However, it does not reset any input values
that have been set to non-default values. Note that setting datapin values
could also implicitly reset some the states of some components.

validation_names

AbstractSet[python:str]

Names of the specific datapins or components that are required to be valid.
Setting names may enable the workflow engine to shortcut evaluation of the
workflow. If the set is non-empty, the workflow engine may choose which
portions of the workflow are run to satisfy the given datapins with the
minimum runtime.

Raises

ValueOutOfRangeError

If one of the input values violates its datapin’s bounds or enumerated values.

Get the root element of the workflow instance.

Name of the element to retrieve in dotted notation. For example,
'Root.Component.Thing'.

title: The iworkflow.py module
text: The iworkflow.py module

title: The iworkflow.py module > Summary
text:
Summary

Interfaces





IWorkflowEngine

Provides the interface for the workflow engine.

IFileBasedWorkflowEngine

Extends the IWorkflowEngine module with calls.

IWorkflowInstance

Represents an instantiated workflow instance.

IElement

Provides a component, control statement, or datapin.

IDatapinContainer

Provides an abstract base class for something that can contain datapins.

IControlStatement

Provides an element in the workflow that contains children and how they are executed.

IComponent

Provides for a black box analysis.

IDatapin

Provides a runtime placeholder for some value of a particular type.

title: The iworkflow.py module > Description
text:
Description

Synchronous API definitions.

This module contains the common API for all Ansys workflow engines, written in a
synchronous style. It has the exact same API as the iasyncworkflow module and any
changes to one file must be made to the other.

Generally speaking, in addition to the exceptions already noted, implementations of
this API may raise the exceptions.EngineInternalError class to indicate
that an internal error has been encountered and should be reported to the engine
implementation maintainer.

title: API reference
text:
API reference

This section describes ansys-engineeringworkflow-api endpoints, their capabilities, and how
to interact with them programmatically.

title: User guide
text:
User guide

The Ansys Engineering Workflow API is not intended for standalone use.
Links to the compatible libraries will soon be available on this page.
